dialogues.text: You stupid bloody idiot. All you had to do was give her jelly. INT. OUTSIDE THE QUEEN’S WRITING ROOM. DAY They’ve reached Ponsonby.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. (Jo Abdul.) She wants you to stand by the writing desk. (Zo Bigge.) He can stand by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdul stands to attention. The Queen is led in with cerem down. Her pens are presented by a flunkey. The flunkey bo off to stand by the door. Abdul is standing to attention side, trying not to show his unease.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I’m not going to eat you. 25 The Queen takes a piece of headed notepaper and starts w To Doctor Reid .. . A very successful movement . . . this morning at eight a.m... .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bigge, various Ladies in Waiting and the two flunkeys. Th to look through the keyhole.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGE
dialogues.text: What’s he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen is deeply absorbed in her letter writing. She s with a flourish. Then suddenly she is surprised by Abdul at her shoulder with a blotter. He blots her writing and

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr...

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Abdul. Abdul Karim. I am always writing. In India. ’m writing all the day, every day.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Really. So in India you’re not a servant.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: No. In India I am writing in my very big book.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You’re writing a book!

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes. I am writing every name, who they are, what they will be. This is my life. Every day I am writing. From th morning to the night.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And this is fiction? 26

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is true. Everything I write is the very truth.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I don’t understand, if you are an author why you are here presenting the . . . thing, the...

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: The mohar. It is my humble privilege to serve Her Majesty I was the one who chose your carpets.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The carpets?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: For the exhibition. The Viceroy asked Mr Tyler but actual it was me. You have to have very good eye for the carpets This is a very nice one. For example. They look at the carpet beneath them.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Very tight knots. This is the sign of a very nice carpet. art of carpets came to India with the great Emperor Akbar The skill of a great carpet is to bring all the different threads together and we weave something we can stand on.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You seem to know an awful lot about it.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: My family were carpet makers. But now I write in the book. Life is like the carpet. We weave in and out to mak a pattern.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How very true. That is a very beautiful image.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: It is a very beautiful carpet. Look at this — here is a b freedom caught forever in the design.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: So in India you are a poet? 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just make a ledger of the prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Indeed we are all prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Indeed we are, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Phipps is listening at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LADY PHIPPS
dialogues.text: Apparently he’s a poet!

dialogues.speaker: BIGGE
dialogues.text: A poet?! Suddenly the doors burst open, out comes the Queen follow Abdul. Mohammed hisses in Hindi:

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: What the hell are you playing at? INT. ABDUL AND MOHAMMED’S CELL. NIGHT A tiny room with two beds squashed together. Mohammed is

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I was just trying to be friendly. Abdul is breathing out, fascinated by his breath freezing

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: Stop being friendly.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: She’s a very nice person.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: She is the tyrannical oppressor of our entire country. And if we don’t get out of here we’ll die of bloody cold. 28 Mohammed wraps himself in his blanket and turns away. Ab carries on blowing out frozen exhalations.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: Will you stop doing that!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARDENS. WINDSOR CASTLE. DAY
dialogues.text: Ponsonby with Dr Reid and Lady Churchill are hiding behin trees so they can spy on the Queen and Abdul. Ponsonby lo binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: You realise this is the third day in a row.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CANOPIED WRITING STATION. WINDSOR CASTLE. DAY
dialogues.text: The Queen finishes writing. Abdul blots her copy. She clo He goes back to ‘standing sentry’. Then the Queen turns h directly to him.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: So Mr Abdul. May I ask you which part of India are you from?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I am from Agra. The Taj Mahal. You have been to the Taj Mahal?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, it is the most marvellous building in the entire worl The Crown of Palaces. It was built by Shah Jahan, the grandson of the great Akbar, to remember his dead wife, Mumtaz Mahal, who died in childhood with their fourteenth child.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Goodness. 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was so upset with grief. He brought the greatest architects from Persia and Afghanistan to build the Taj Mahal.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It certainly sounds like a handsome building. I would ver much like to see it.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, it is beautiful, Your Majesty. All white marble. And Mumtaz laid inside. All of that beauty for the dead Queen

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How romantic.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes. And he wrote a poem: ‘The sight of this building brings me sad sighs; ‘The sun and the moon have tears in their eyes.’ But it makes everyone so happy. Agra is very beautiful. Shah Jahan built the Red Fort, the Gardens of Shalimar, and the Peacock Throne.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The Peacock Throne?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, it was the most beautiful throne in all the world. A throne of gold with peacocks on it. And in the throne was the Koh-i-Noor. He would look at the Taj Mahal through the diamond.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But I have the Koh-i-Noor. I have it as a brooch.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Do you?!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It was given to me by the East India Company. It wasn’t very shiny so Albert had it recut. So what happened to th Peacock Throne? 30

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don’t know, they smashed it up.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How awful.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, they are always smashing things up. All the British soldiers have taken the jewels from the Taj Mahal.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: British soldiers?!

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes, after the Mutiny.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But this is terrible.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: At least you have the diamond.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GARDENS. WINDSOR CASTLE. DAY
dialogues.text: Dr Reid looking through the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: What can they be talking about? An Indian and a servant to boot. Lady Churchill grabs the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: What on earth does she see in him? We see Abdul from Lady Churchill’s point of view.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Well, he is rather handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen Victoria continues talking to Abdul as they walk. 31

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what happened to Shah Jahan?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: He was overthrown by his son and died in Agra Fort.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The wickedness of children.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: They buried him in the Taj Mahal next to his wife. They put an inscription: ‘Here lies Shah Jahan who left this w to the Banquet Hall of Eternity’

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The Banquet Hall of Eternity.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes, it is a banquet when we leave here.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I rather like that idea. You seem very well informed, Mr Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, these are famous stories in Uttar Pradesh. You should go there.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh, I can never go there. I am forbidden.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Forbidden?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: They fear I would be assassinated.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: But you are the Empress of India.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Exactly. (Proudly.) You know I’ve been shot at four times And someone came for me with a knife! 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness. So you have never seen an India street, or a st of spices.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, the spices. Cardamom, turmeric, cumin, coriander. Garam masala.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What is garam masala?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: It’s what you put into the sauce. You have never tasted Indian food? A dahl? A rogan josh? Oh they are the greate dishes in the world! Biryani with mango chutney?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Mango chutney?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes, a chutney made of mango.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: A mango?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, the mango is the Queen of Fruit.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What does it taste like?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: A mango is the most delicious fruit in all the world. Lik orange and a peach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ponsonby and the ladies in waiting are accompanying Queen down the corridor. Abdul and Mohammed in tow. 33

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ponsonby. I would like a mango.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: A mango?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Yes, I would like to taste a mango.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: It’s impossible. They only grow in India, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam the Empress of India, so have one sent. I hope you will like Scotland, Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOP OF THE MOOR. SCOTLAND. DAY
dialogues.text: Scottish mists. The vast landscape of Scotland. A train o come into shot carrying tables, chairs, carpets. Ponsonby Churchill, Miss Phipps and Reid struggle up with them. Qu Victoria comes into view close to the camera. She points

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Here!

dialogues.text: Queen Victoria is sitting at her ‘tea’ table, formally se with every unnecessary accoutrement. It overlooks spectac but Queen Victoria behaves as if she was in her back gard and Mohammed stand to attention in the background. Mohamm sneezes. Butlers and maids serve the tea. Queen Victoria wrapped up. She gorges herself on a sponge cake. Everyone and miserable. Ponsonby whispers to Dr Reid:

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: It’s alright for her. She’s upholstered. The hand of the serving man shakes as he pours the tea.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How do you like your new Scottish costumes? 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re very scratchy, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Everything in Scotland is scratchy. (Jo Ponsonby.) When does Bertie come?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, Your Majesty. He is on his way from Monte Carlo. The Queen takes a slurp of the tea then puts the cup on t Suddenly there’s a splish in the teacup. Then a pitter-pa the table cloth.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VICINITY OF THE WILD PROMONTORY. SCOTLAND. DAY

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Thate Scotland.

The Quee at the centre and is tapping her foot delicately as one o doing a dance in front of her. There is forced merriment Mohammed and Abdul are standing at the side, watching the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: GHILLIE
dialogues.text: (in incomprehensible Scots) Ye must be the Hindoos. Very nice to meet ye. Incomprehension from Abdul and Mohammed.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: More! More!

dialogues.speaker: GHILLIE

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: And the blank journal you requested. Ponsonby puts on his glasses and takes a pen out of his p to get down to work.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: ‘You may go. Ponsonby waits. He is confused. 36

dialogues.text: Iam perfectly capable of working through the boxes. Abdul is very helpful with his blotter.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam aware of that.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: But Abdul is a servant. He cannot assist with the boxes.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam the Queen of England. I will have whatever help with my boxes that I require. Ponsonby is completely banjaxed by the turn of events. INT. THE SAME, OUTSIDE THE QUEEN’S ROOM Ponsonby emerges wiping his brow. Mohammed is standing ou room, as is Lady Churchill. They look to Ponsonby to disc royal news.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: He’s helping her with the boxes. INT. THE SAME, QUEEN’S STUDY Now the Queen and Abdul are alone she turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I want you to teach me Indian.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Indian?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Hindu. Whatever it is you speak.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Are you sure? 37

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I am sure.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: But why would you want to speak Hindi?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam Empress of India. Look. I have ordered a book. I want you to give me private lessons.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I can’t teach you Hindi.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Why ever not?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: You are the Empress of India. You must learn Urdu. The language of the Mughals. Oh there are a thousand languages in India but Urdu is the most noble. The difference is when you write it down. In Urdu you write like this. He demonstrates it. This is Persian script. Just like Arabic. And for Hindi y write like this — in Devanagari: He demonstrates. The Persian script is most superior.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Isee.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Iam the Queen. Mairn raini hoom.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Er donny hoo.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Mairn raini hoom.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Hey Donnneee whoo. 38

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoom —

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Hoowm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gaggle of Ladies in Waiting and members of the Househ bigger and they are listening outside, full of consternat

dialogues.speaker: LADY PHIPPS
dialogues.text: He’s teaching her Hindi!

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: Urdu, actually: the Muslim version. They are aghast. INT. QUEEN’S STUDY

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Mairn raini hoom.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Mer ranee whoo.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: That’s it! That’s it! You are the Queen. He writes it down. You see. Now you...

dialogues.text: She’s writing in the journal. And she’s speaking in Hindustani.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Urdu, actually. The Muslim version. Mohammed raises an eyebrow. 39  INT. QUEEN’S STUDY The Queen is laughing as she tries to repeat Abdul’s phra

dialogues.text: Apanni trishnup kili ap abdu tel new ad.

dialogues.text: Apanni trishnup kili ap abdu tel new ad.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Apni. Ni. Abdul slaps his knees.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Knee. Knee.

dialogues.text: Apani utkrsta sabaka kelie apa abdula dhan yavada. Thank you, Abdul, for your excellent lesson.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Apani utkrsta sabaka kelie apa abdula dhan yavada!

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: That’s it. You did it. Now write it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new fat arse is on show as its owner bends in to look t keyhole. The doors fly open. The arse stands up straight.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Bertie!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mother!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Were you spying on me? 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you learning Urdu?!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Yes, I was, as a matter of fact.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Do you think that’s entirely appropriate?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam the Empress of India. What could be more appropriate than learning Urdu?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: But in front of the entire Household —

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You are absolutely right. I can’t have all of these distractions. Ponsonby, I wish to go to Glassalt Shiel.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Glassalt Shiel?! Everybody is surprised. She looks at Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Alone.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: But I’ve only just got here.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LOCHSIDE, DAY
dialogues.text: Drone shot of stunning scenery of the lochside. A tiny bo moves towards a white cottage set against the lowering mo beyond.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE LITTLE HOUSE, GLASSALT SHIEL. DAY
dialogues.text: Queen and Abdul on the promontory.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh, to be by oneself and live a simple rudimentary existence.

dialogues.speaker: 4I
dialogues.text: She turns to Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: They don’t understand anything, those stupid aristocratic fools. Toadying around. Jockeying for position. I’ve had my whole life. They couldn’t bear me bringing dear John Brown here. Yet I have been happier here than anywhere in the entire world. Oh, I miss him, Abdul. And Albert. It’s been thirty years and I think about him every day. I am s lonely, Abdul. Everyone I really loved has died. And I ju go on and on and on. She weeps.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, Your Majesty. Abdul kneels and wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It’s an impossible position. No one really knows what it like to be Queen. I am hated by millions of people — all over the world. I have had nine children, all vain and jealous, and completely at loggerheads with each other. Bertie is a complete embarrassment. I have thirty-four grandchildren, my offspring will rule most of Europe — bu look at me: a fat, lame, impotent, silly old woman. What the point, Abdul?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: The point, Your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Of life?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Service.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Service?!

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I think we are not here to worry about ourselves. We are here to serve a greater purpose. 42  Queen Victoria thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: In the Koran it says: we are here for the good of others.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The Koran? Abdul is trying to cheer up Her Majesty with his enthusia

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I am a Hafiz. I know the Koran by heart.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: By heart. Isn’t it very long?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: There are 114 Surahs containing 6,236 verses.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And you know every word?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Many Muslim people know the Koran.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I thought you were a Hindu.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Iam a Muslim, Your Majesty. I learnt the Koran from my father. And he taught me all the great poets: Kabir, Rumi He is my Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Munshi?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Yes, Munshi. My teacher.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Then we would like you to be the Queen’s Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: But I am a servant. A servant cannot be a Munshi? 43

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you are a servant no longer. You are my teacher. Yo shall teach me Urdu and the Koran and anything else you think of.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL. BALMORAL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A dozen local guests are waiting for the dinner. Mohammed standing with a tray of sherry. Across the room Ponsonby, Miss Phipps, Lady Churchill and Dr Reid are gathered in a

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What the hell is a Munshi?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Apparently it’s some sort of ‘spiritual teacher’, Your Ro Highness.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Has she completely lost her mind?! She’s the head of the Church of England, for God’s sake! What’s the Archbishop of Canterbury going to say?

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: It’s utter lunacy.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: I say he’s ‘brown’ John Brown.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: And what’s more she’s given him my room!

dialogues.speaker: MISS PHIPPS
dialogues.text: But where have they put you, Dr Reid?

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: (with a hateful look to Ponsonby) In the tower! Bertie suddenly sees the Queen arrive with Abdul in tow i magnificent Munshi garb.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Oh my God. 44  Bertie looks horrified as the Queen approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Good evening, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mother?! Aside Mohammed whispers to Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: What the hell are you wearing? Before Bertie can question Queen Victoria about this turn Head Waiter announces:

dialogues.speaker: HEAD WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie with Queen Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Lady Churchill was absolutely scandalised. A servant. And a Hindoo to boot!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The Munshi is a Muslim scholar. He knows the Koran off by heart and for your information is no longer a servant. He is to be given a staff of his own.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: This is absurd. Letters. Invitations to supper. You’re tr him like family.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: No, I like Abdul. Lady Churchill had better get used to t fact — as the Munshi is coming on holiday with us as a fu equal member of the Household.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You can’t take a Muslim to Florence! 45

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be all. The Queen walks off upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RAILWAY CARRIAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: The train is trundling along. Mohammed blows his nose int handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: A spiritual advisor!? You haven’t an idea in your head. Y promised to get us out of here. And now we’re going to bloody Florence.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: But don’t you see what a privilege it is to see the glori Italy with all these wonderful people?

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: You complete bloody idiot. Do you really think they are going to stand there and let her promote a wog? I did not come here to carry your bloody cases.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: What you are complaining about? We have our own carriage. With a bathroom. They’ve a very nice bed for you on the floor. Mohammed blows his nose.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: I’m dying here. I want to go home. I am telling you this whole thing is a disaster waiting to happen.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Iam getting sick of your negative attitude. Life is a big adventure. You just need to open up and enjoy it. We’re o holiday. What on earth could possibly go wrong? Abdul sees a rope above him — he grabs hold of it and rea sign beside it.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: ‘Do Not Pull’ 46  INT. QUEEN’S CARRIAGE. TRAIN. LATER The baroque splendour of the Queen’s carriage. The Queen Abdul is there.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I just want to apologise about the emergency brake, Your Majesty. I hope you weren’t too badly injured.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It was nothing at all, Abdul. Anyway, it’s a completely understandable mistake. I am just so glad you are with us What a treat to show you Florence for the first time. Bertie emerges from the royal bathroom in his pyjamas to

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What’s he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Abdul was just explaining what happened earlier.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I really don’t see why I have to share your bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I shared a bed with my mother until I became Queen.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mother, I am fifty-seven years old. The Munshi’s got his own bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh yes, it is a very fine bathroom indeed, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He has to push his way past Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Ma-mah.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mr Bertie. 47

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie. Make sure you shut that door. Bertie pushes past Abdul unhappily and leaves. The Queen Abdul’s hand

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Abdul, I have something for you. To celebrate your first to Florence. And becoming my Munshi. It is a locket. With a picture of me. She gives him a locket.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh Your Majesty! How can I ever thank you.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Keep me safe.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: For ever, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh Abdul. You will love Florence. Such wonderful views.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GARDENS, VILLA PALMIERI. DAY
dialogues.text: Abdul and Queen Victoria are walking in the Italianate ga the terrace of the Villa Palmieri, Mohammed standing sent background.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Isn’t it glorious. Albert loved it here. The Brunelleschi Dome. The Uffizi Gallery. He spent all of his money on Old Masters. We collected so much I had to give most of i to the National Gallery. He so admired the Medicis. That they would commission the greatest artists of the day. So they could leave something astonishing behind.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: In India we also commision great artists. Each Mughal Emperor would bring the greatest craftsmen to make great glories for their Durbar Room. 48

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Durbar Room?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, every Emperor had a Durbar Room. Full of the finest things known to man.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well, Iam the Empress of India. I should have a Durbar Room.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: A brilliant idea, Your Majesty. But where would you put i

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The Isle of Wight. Obviously. Ponsonby arrives.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Signor Puccini has arrived, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: We are in the middle of the recital. The Royal Household to a fat man singing ‘Donna non vidi mai’ at the piano. A listening intently next to the Queen, Bertie next to Lady Ponsonby says something to Dr Reid. The Munshi turns:

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Ssshhhh! The fat man at the piano finishes his song. Abdul applaud enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And where did you say it was from, Mr Puccini?

dialogues.speaker: PUCCINI
dialogues.text: It’s from my new opera Manon Lescaut. It’s about two lovers separated by the class divide who run away togethe

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It sounds marvellous. 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she is imprisoned for her love, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: PUCCINI
dialogues.text: But they escape.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Bravo.

dialogues.speaker: PUCCINI
dialogues.text: But finally she dies, leaving him utterly bereft.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I’m not sure we do like the sound of it. We prefer comic opera. Do you know any Gilbert and Sullivan?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Perhaps Your Majesty will sing us a song?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh no. I couldn’t possibly. The Household on cue:

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: But please, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (aside) God save us!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well, just one. From Pinafore. Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Do I have to? Bertie, reluctantly, goes to the piano.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: ‘Little Buttercup’. In C. Bertie sits at the piano with immense reluctance. Queen V 50 ‘Little Buttercup’ poorly. She dries, is about to contin prompts the applause.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Bravo! More! More! But to everyone’s relief Puccini produces a glass of cham hands it to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: PUCCINI
dialogues.text: Bellissimo, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I was taught by Mendelssohn, you know. Puccini raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: PUCCINI
dialogues.text: To the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: To me. She knocks back the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TERRACE, FLORENCE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Queen is tipsy. She holds on to Abdul’s arm as they w the terrace in the warm evening air, Florence twinkling b and Lady Churchill look on aghast. The Queen is singing t of the Gilbert and Sullivan song:

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: La, la, la, la, la, la. She lifts her arm as she walks, half dancing. We should not have drunk all that champagne. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: May I? Abdul takes the Queen’s other hand and they waltz their w the terrace, la-la-ing’ an accompaniment. We are close up 51 almost childish pleasure. Finally the Queen and Abdul st come to a stop. Abdul smiling at the Queen. Still holding

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Abdul, I have not been so happy for years.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: When I came to England, I was terrified of you. But you are a very kind lady. You are a very unique lady to me.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And you are very, very ‘unique’ to me, Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I know that you are very much older than me. And you are the Queen of England and Empress of India and I am just a humble Munshi. But I think you are the most special person in my whole life. His eyes are alight. They look at each other intimately.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Even more special than my wife.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: (shocked) Wife?!

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Yes. The Queen is computing this information, her face severe.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You are married?!

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But where is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: In India.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me you were married? 52

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn’t think it mattered.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: (severely) Of course, this changes everything. You will have to retu to India immediately. Abdul looks concerned. And bring her back at once!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. ISLE OF WIGHT. DAY
dialogues.text: A shot of Osborne House. Huge music as a carriage approac INT. THE SAME, QUEEN’S BEDCHAMBER The Queen is sitting with her journal practising her Urdu

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Aaj kal Agra ka msusam kesa hay? [How is the weather in Agra these days?] Mrs Tuck runs in.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TUCK
dialogues.text: He’s coming! INT. QUEEN’S DRESSING ROOM/BEDCHAMBER. DAY The Queen passes a mirror, checks her appearance, then da the room.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: A carriage races down the drive and into the circle in fr House.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOP OF THE STAIRS, OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Queen Victoria rushes past maids who jump to attention as round a corner and dashes past Ponsonby and Dr Reid, who her whizz by in amazement. 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music of Triumphant Return continues as the carriage stand still. Mohammed is waiting by the door. He blows hi

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: Bloody hell. And rushes towards the carriage to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GLAZED TERRACE, OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: The Queen is now looking out from the terrace with great

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How terribly exciting!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Mohammed runs, ignominiously, over the gravel to open the the carriage. We cut back to Osborne House. There are exp at every window. The terrace is crowded with Household me Mohammed opens the carriage door. Abdul emerges from the He steps down resplendent in his ceremonial outfit, doubl replete with sword and pistol, and the Star of India. He cross between a Maharajah and a Pirate King and rather fa before. Mohammed is unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: (under his breath) For God’s sake!

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIRST FLOOR TERRACE, OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Bertie, Lady Churchill, Miss Phipps are gathered with Ali looking down at Abdul’s arrival.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Look at the size of him.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And he’s got a sword. 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a pistol!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdul holds out his hand and Mrs Karim emerges from the c in full burga.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIRST FLOOR TERRACE, OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: There is an audible gasp from Miss Phipps.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What the devil is she wearing?

dialogues.speaker: MISS PHIPPS
dialogues.text: You can’t even see her face!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: A skinny serving boy, Ahmed, gets out of the carriage. He around amazed at his surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIRST-FLOOR TERRACE, OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Now Dr Reid and Ponsonby are out on the terrace — further from Bertie and the Ladies in Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Who the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Abdul cuffs Ahmed on the ear, bringing him ‘to’.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: The bags. The bags! Ahmed runs to help Mohammed with Mrs Karim’s bags. Mrs Ka stands resplendent. 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen looks on delighted.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I think she looks rather splendid.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TUCK
dialogues.text: But you can’t actually see her, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I think it’s rather dignified.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Abdul turns and helps another fully burga’d lady from the

dialogues.speaker: INT. FIRST FLOOR TERRACE, OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Another scandalised gasp from the company.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Another one! How many has he got in there?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The ruddy sod’s a bigamist!

dialogues.speaker: MISS PHIPPS
dialogues.text: (delighted) This is an absolute scandal!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Abdul stands with his two burqua’d ladies while Mohammed Ahmed get bags from the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GLAZED TERRACE. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: The Queen looks on.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I do hope they like their little cottage. 56  INT. ABDUL’S COTTAGE. DAY A knock at the door. Abdul opens the door to find the Que

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I hope it’s not inconvenient. I just thought we’d pop rou for tea.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OTTAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: A chocolate-box cottage on the Osborne Estate. We see the accompanied by a vast entourage of people. INT. TINY LIVING ROOM, ABDUL’S COTTAGE. DAY A ‘tableau’ of Queen Victoria, Ponsonby, Lady Churchill, of Greece (1870-1932), the Grand Duchess Sophie of Saxe-W Eisenach (1824-97), Princess Helena of Schleswig-Holstein Sonderburg-Augustenburg (1848-1923), and their entourages Mohammed, Abdul, Ahmed, Mrs Karim and the mother-in-law a with the usual entourage, plus the retinue of the royal v squashed tightly in Abdul’s tiny living room. Bertie and perched on travel cases because of the lack of chairs.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: This is my granddaughter, Sophia, The Queen of Greece, this is the Grand Duchess Sophie of Saxe-Weimar- Eisenach, and my daughter, Princess Helena Augusta Viktoria of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg-Augustenburg.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: A pleasure to meet you. This is my wife Mrs Karim, and this is my mother-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: How very nice to meet you. How are you enjoying England, Mrs Karim? Abdul translates this — at great length — to his missus. something to him — also at great length, then...

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: She says: ‘Very well. Thank you, Your Majesty.’ 57 The Munshi’s wife then whispers to him again for an inte long time. Everyone waits politely. Finally he turns and

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: ‘Apart from the cold’ They laugh gently.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (aside) God help me.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, Sophia — the Queen of Greece, Grand Duchess Sophie of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, Princess Helena Augusta Viktoria of Schleswig-Holstein-Sonderburg- Augustenburg, I would like to take this opportunity on behalf of myself, my wife and my wife’s mother to thank Her Majesty Victoria Regina of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, Empress of India, for accommodating us in this beautiful cottage. We are extremely grateful for her infinite kindness and interior decoration. The gift of hospitality and friendsh to strangers is of very high importance in our culture an we are honoured to repay it in our very small way. What i ours is yours.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Quite literally.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: And this is how the world should be. Here we are, representatives of the great nations of the world, all snuggled together, having a nice cup of Indian tea. Thank be to Allah. Queen Victoria leads the polite applause.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: My dear Munshi, Mrs Karim and Mrs Karim’s mother — it’s so good to have you back, my children. We have misse you enormously. 58  EXT. ABDUL’S COTTAGE. DAY A groom and pony-driven carriage wait for the Queen. The visitors are leaving. Bertie marches up the path, Ponsonb following close behind:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Children?! Dr Reid is on Ponsonby’s heels.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: (aside, to Ponsonby) If they are going to live here can I get my room back? The Queen is the last to leave. She takes his hand:

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh Abdul, I am so glad you are back — it really has been dreadfully dull without you. And I am so glad to meet Mrs Karim. There’s just one thing I’ve been curious about thi whole afternoon. What does Mrs Karim look like behind her veil?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Behind her veil? You must see her.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Is that allowed?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Of course it is allowed. You are a lady. And the Empress of India.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Really?! You think she’d let me take a glimpse?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: She would be honoured, Your Majesty. Ponsonby and Bertie at the end of the garden path.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Where the hell is she going now? 59  INT. TINY LIVING ROOM, ABDUL’S COTTAGE. DAY Queen Victoria is sitting on a chair. Mrs Karim takes off We glimpse the gorgeous costume underneath, full of colou see her face. Her nose is pierced with a gold chain linke She giggles like a schoolgirl. Victoria is transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Oh, you really are beautiful. Mrs Karim giggles again, not understanding a word. The Qu stands and takes both of her hands:

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Tum bahut sundar ho. [You are very beautiful.] Mrs Karim beams. Her mother watches inscrutably from her Abdul looks on at the whole scene, proud as Punch.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Main tum yahaan hai bahut khush hoon. [I am so happy to have you here.]

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: A carriage arrives. Ponsonby is waiting for Lord Salisbur gets out.

dialogues.speaker: LORD SALISBURY
dialogues.text: What on earth is a Durbar Room?

dialogues.speaker: INT. OSBORNE, CORRIDOR APPROACHING DURBAR ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: The Prime Minister, Lord Salisbury, is marching up a corr followed by his private secretary and deputy private secr face filled with fury. Bertie and Ponsonby are running al

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: It is a celebration of all things Indian inspired by the Mughal Emperors, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: LORD SALISBURY
dialogues.text: But I don’t understand. Who gave her permission to build this in the first place? 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don’t blame me. I was in Monte Carlo.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I’m afraid she is a law unto herself, Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: LORD SALISBURY
dialogues.text: For God’s sake. She’ll be wearing a burga next. I am holding you entirely responsible, Ponsonby. They have arrived at the Queen, who is waiting with Dr Re Churchill, Miss Phipps and the usual entourage.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Prime Minister, you are late.

dialogues.speaker: LORD SALISBURY
dialogues.text: I’m terribly sorry, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Let us begin.

dialogues.speaker: INT. INDIAN CORRIDOR. DAY
dialogues.text: The Queen leads Salisbury, Ponsonby, Bertie, etc. down th corridor.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: This, as you can see, is the Indian corridor. The Durbar Room was designed by Mr Bhai Ram Singh. They pass a smiling Mr Bhai Ram Singh.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (in Salisbury’s ear) The place is crawling with them.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And we commissioned a series of portraits. Of eminent Indians. This is Princess Gurmma. Lord Salisbury tries to feign interest as he looks at the

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: This, of course . . . is the Munshi. 61 Salisbury looks horrified at the portrait of Abdul. Then upon the real Abdul who is in full Munshi uniform, a flow Abdul beams at the Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: An honour to meet you, Mr Prime Minister, sir.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: A very good likeness. Don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: (whispering to Lord Salisbury) I asked him to take a few pounds off. This is my wife, Mr Prime Minister, sir, and this is my mother-in-law. The two ladies are by his side in their identical burgas. At least I think that’s the right way round. Abdul chuckles at his own joke. And this is my servant, Mohammed. Mohammed blows his nose. Ahmed is there.

dialogues.speaker: LORD SALISBURY
dialogues.text: (aside to Ponsonby) What the hell is going on here, Ponsonby?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And this, Prime Minister, is the Durbar Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salisbury follows the Queen into the Durbar Room in all i It is a state room decorated in an over-the-top higgledy- Mughal and Hindu motifs. Indian musicians play from the b The Queen walks through the room pointing out the carving

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: The carvings are all from Uttar Pradesh. And the carpet: The carpet was woven in a gaol in Agra. Perfect, of cours for the tableaux. 62  At the end of the room is the Peacock Throne.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And the piéce de résistance. The Peacock Throne. The Queen sits on the throne. An exact copy of the one in Agra. And, of course, the Koh-i-Noor! She is wearing the Koh-i-Noor brooch.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Now I really do feel like the Empress of India. She is like a little child, swinging her feet joyously. S household deputation look on at her:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (aside to Dr Reid) I thought she was supposed to be dying.

dialogues.speaker: LORD SALISBURY
dialogues.text: It really is a remarkable addition to the house, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: We have Abdul to thank for the whole idea.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: (who is now standing next to the Queen) Oh, really — it was nothing. Ponsonby steps forward, very formally.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: To celebrate the completion of the Durbar Room. A little surprise, Your Majesty. Mohammed appears bearing an ornately inlaid box. The Quee the box and looks inside. Pulling a confused face:

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: A mango, Your Majesty. 63  A general gasp. Abdul peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: It’s ‘off’. A look of horror on everyone’s face.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Ponsonby. This mango is off. Ponsonby’s chagrin. INT. LADIES’ DRESSING ROOM, OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT Lady Churchill, Miss Phipps, and various other ladies fro entourage in petticoats getting undressed. Helped by Mrs

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: A line has definitively been crossed. INT. MEN’S DRESSING ROOM. OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT Abdul is getting changed into his Sultan of Persia outfit wipes his brow and sits down, shaking with a fever.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: This is a complete and utter disaster.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: They’ve been waiting for this.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Who have?

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: Ponsonby, Reid. The whole damn lot of them. Don’t you see, she’s been rubbing their noses in it but now it’s go public. I’m telling you they’re not going to stand for it they’ll rise up and chop your bloody balls off. You’ve up the order of everything. You think they are going to lie and take it? 64

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I haven’t done anything.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: You stupid, bloody Uncle Tom. Don’t you see you’ve upset the order of everything. I’m telling you this whole thing complete catastrophe. Abdul looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: ALICK YORKE
dialogues.text: Everything alright in here?

dialogues.speaker: INT. DURBAR ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Now the Durbar Room has been transformed. A large stage w plush velvet curtain has been erected at one end and domi room. The room is crammed with people ready to see the ta Bigge, Reid, Ponsonby, all the staff in the rear rows cra arrival of Mrs Karim and Mrs Karim’s mother. The Queen raises her hand and waves at Mrs Karim.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Mrs Munshi! Please, sit here. Bertie. Bertie, much put out, is forced to move. Salisbury watche thing in horror. INT. LADIES’ DRESSING ROOM. NIGHT Lady Churchill puts on her a yashmak and looks in the mir

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: I have never been so humiliated in my entire life.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DURBAR ROOM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The lights in the hall have dimmed. Music. The Queen sque Karim’s hand. Alick Yorke appears from between the curtai

dialogues.speaker: ALICK YORKE
dialogues.text: A scene in Ancient Persia. 65 He withdraws. Ponsonby pops a pill. The Queen is agog wi anticipation. The curtains open to reveal painted flats. Ancient Persia. Lady Churchill, Miss Phipps and Mrs Tuck dressed in Persian costumes. They pose as a harem of supp Abdul, dressed as the Sultan of Persia with Ahmed as his Mohammed is at the back sick with fever.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Iam the Sultan of Persia, King of all Kings. You are now under my power.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Your Highness. We bestow all the riches of the Orient upo you. The ladies proffer paste jewels. Abdul tries his best to regal. They all look out uneasily at the audience trying matey rictus as the orchestra swells and they hold the ta is in the way — Abdul surreptitiously cuffs him to clear We notice Mohammed swaying, clearly ill, and just as the descends as everyone else is fixed in the tableau, Mohamm Lord Salisbury is open-mouthed. Ponsonby holds his forehe despair. The Queen is unabashed with her approval.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Bravo! Bravo the Munshi!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (aside to Dr Reid) Now she thinks he’s Henry Irving. As the curtain opens for the ‘call’, the Queen leaps to h entire household follow suit, applauding politely. Only M her mother remain seated. Abdul gestures his respects to and bows egregiously. She claps enthusiastically. The cur again. Salisbury is not happy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Lord Salisbury bollocks Ponsonby.

dialogues.speaker: LORD SALISBURY
dialogues.text: What the hell is this, Ponsonby? Munshi-mania? I’m trying 66 to keep an empire together and it looks like they’re run the place. I want this whole sodding mess knocked on the head or you’re finished. Understood? Lord Salisbury turns and leaves leaving Ponsonby chagrine

dialogues.speaker: INT. POST-TABLEAU ROOM, OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The post-tableau soirée. Victoria is sitting amongst the members of the household, drinking sherry. Ponsonby, batt comes in to join them.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Ah, Ponsonby. Tell us, what exactly did the Prime Ministe say about the tableau?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: To be entirely frank, Your Majesty, he seemed to be a lit perturbed.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Whatever for? He must have liked the Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I think the Munshi was the problem, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Really? I thought he was rather good.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I think he meant his position, Your Majesty. I think he was rather alarmed he had such a prominent role in the Household.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Of course Abdul has a prominent role in the household. He is my Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: But he’s an Indian, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam aware of it. 67

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But given current sensitivities in the sub-continent, You Majesty. The Prime Minister was concerned it might be ‘sending the wrong message’.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I should have thought it was a jolly good message.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: But he’s a Muslim, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Precisely. We owe them so much, do we not? For their role in the Mutiny, for example. The hubbub drops to a deathly silence.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: The Mutiny, Your Majesty?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Yes. For all the help they gave us with the Hindus.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: But the Mutiny was a Muslim-led revolt, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Of course. The Muslim soldiers revolted when it was rumoured their rifles were greased with pork fat.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: The Grand Mufti, himself, put out a fatwa against you personally. And Muslim soldiers killed over two thousand British personnel.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Who have you been talking to, Mother? 68 Suddenly Abdul arrives with a flourish in his smartest M

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Ta-da! The Queen glares at him. Everyone else is staring. He rea something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SCULPTURE CORRIDOR. OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Queen is standing next to Abdul in the corridor, givi furious dressing down.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Ihave opened my heart to you. I have brought your family from India, promoted you in the teeth of very considerabl opposition and disquiet from the Household. I even turned a blind eye when you failed to tell me you were married, which came, as you know, as quite a surprise. How could you let me humiliate myself in front of the entire Househ

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Iam deeply sorry, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You said the Hindus were behind the Mutiny!

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: I didn’t say it was only the Hindus, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You told me categorically that the Muslims were my friends.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: But we are your friends, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Abdul, there is a fatwa against me. It was Muslims who started the whole thing! This is completely unacceptable. Abdul, I thought you were outstanding as the Sultan of Persia, but I’m afraid you will have to go home. 69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie, Lady Churchill and Dr Reid have gathered and are the conversation. Unable to repress his delight:

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abdul is knocked for six.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You have hurt my feelings very much indeed, Abdul. Don’t you see what a position I have been put in? Thank you for everything you’ve done for me. She starts to leave. She turns and faces Abdul. We can se looking on behind her. I will miss you a very great deal. She turns and walks down the corridor. Queen Victoria marches along the corridor passing Bertie, and Lady Churchill, who dutifully follow her, smirking li have got the cream. Abdul is standing devastated. We see Mohammed has been wa

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: So we’re going home. He starts to cough.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SCULPTURE CORRIDOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Victoria walks along the corridor followed by the smirkin Reid and Lady Churchill. The Queen stops at the end stair Mrs Tuck. Victoria turns to face Bertie, Reid and Churchi suddenly adopt an appropriately solemn demeanour.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mother. 7o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight. The Queen eyes them suspiciously — she knows she’s been h try to keep straight faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen turns and struggles up the stairs. Reid’s face a smile. INT. QUEEN’S BEDCHAMBER. OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT The Queen on her dressing stool, unnerved. She looks up a of Abdul on her wall: Abdul standing proudly as she sits She thinks.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Mrs Tuck! INT. ABDUL’S COTTAGE. NIGHT Pouring rain. It is Mrs Tuck under an umbrella. Abdul is

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LANE OUTSIDE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Victoria is in her pony and trap. Abdul is standing by th an umbrella held by Mrs Tuck.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Abdul, you have been an utter fool and I am absolutely furious with you. It is unconscionable that as my Munshi you should have lied to me in any way. But also it would completely churlish not to recognise the considerable kindness and devotion you’ve shown. And after all, I am sure you thought in some way you were protecting me. But as the monarch, I do realise nothing can really protect m And in that light I have decided, even though I am very disappointed, I would like you to stay. Abdul is astonished. 71

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it must never happen again.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh Your Gracious Majesty. How can I ever thank you?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well, there is something we really must sort out, Abdul. Abdul has no idea what she could mean. Iam deeply concerned about Mrs Karim. INT. QUEEN’S BEDROOM. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY The Queen is having breakfast in bed attended by Dr Reid, and Mrs Tuck.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I want you to examine Mrs Karim.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Examine Mrs Karim?!

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Just make sure everything’s working.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: But I thought the Munshi and his family were leaving us, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Whatever gave you that impression? Astonishment from all and sundry. The Munshi and his family are an integral part of the Roy Household. And I would be very grateful if you gave her a thorough examination. She blithely goes back to work on her egg. Dr Reid looks

dialogues.speaker: INT. OSBORNE HOUSE. TOP OF STAIRS. DAY
dialogues.text: Bertie, Ponsonby and Reid descending the stairs. 72

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as I’m concerned this is war. We’re going to dig u every last piece of shit the blaggard’s ever done. I want someone in India raking through the family coals. Isn’t your son out there, Ponsonby?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t possibly be involved in subterfuge, Your Majes

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Look. I’m going to be the one in charge very soon. You’ll do as you’re bloody well told. I want no stone unturned. We are going to make a dossier. Have it all down in black and white; and put an end to this for good. Bertie leaves. Ponsonby looks at Dr Reid.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Well, I better go and examine Mrs Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COTTAGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Dr Reid is sitting awkwardly on a chair, a stethoscope ro clearly very unhappy. The Munshi’s wife is in full burga sitting on the side of the bed. Her mother, also in full her holding her hand. Dr Reid looks at Mrs Karim awkwardl turns to Abdul who is waiting anxiously by the doctor’s s

dialogues.speaker: REID
dialogues.text: I need to see her tongue.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Oh, it is not possible to uncover a lady’s mouth, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: REID
dialogues.text: But how can I tell anything if I can’t see her tongue? Abdul speaks to the mother-in-law in Hindi, the mother-in to Mrs Karim. Then she daintily lifts her yashmak a fract sticks out her tongue. The doctor looks at it gingerly th back behind the veil as quickly as it appeared.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Well? 73

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she’s fine. INT. OUTSIDE MOHAMMED’S ROOM. DAY Ponsonby and Bertie are in the servants’ corridor. Ponson on a door. INT. MOHAMMED’S ROOM. DAY Bertie and Ponsonby are in Mohammed’s room. Mohammed has declined since we last saw him.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Mr Mohammed. We have come here because we are not unaware of your predicament. That you arrived in the firs place almost by accident and find yourself stuck here through a bizarre set of circumstances — none of your own making. It is not beneath our notice that the inclement English weather, especially on the Solent, has been the cause of a precipitous decline in your general health and what’s more you continue to suffer the vast indignity of being a servant to someone who is in many ways your inferior, who seems to discharge his role with increasing abuse and disregard. But it has occurred to us that we might be able to offer you some help.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: Help?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Travel home, medical care, perhaps a modest pension. In return, of course, for a little information.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: What sort of information?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Look, I’m not going to beat about the bush. You’ve borne the brunt of Abdul’s appalling behaviour and that is of a great deal of interest to a lot of people. 74

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to dish the dirty?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: In a manner of speaking. Mohammed coughs into his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: What would you like me to say?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Anything really.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: We need details. What he says, what he does. Mohammed thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: Abdul does what everybody else does. Looks for preferment ‘Curries’ favour. Crawls up the stinking greasy pole of t shitty British Empire. Making fools of you all because he a servant — an Indian, Muslim servant — and you are all quaking in your boots because he’s beating you at your ow game.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No one is quaking in their boots. We are the most powerfu nation on Earth at the height of our influence.

dialogues.speaker: MOHAMMED
dialogues.text: In that case the only way is down. So stick your stupid British Empire up your stinky royal bottom-hole, Mr Berti Prince, sir. I hope he makes the whole damn thing come tumbling down. He coughs into his handkerchief. There is blood. Mohammed shocked. Ponsonby looks on in pity.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: T’ll see that you die here. 75

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie and Ponsonby in a cabal with Dr Reid.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: What do you mean, he wouldn’t say anything?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The man’s a complete shit.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: (out of shot) Dr Reid! The Queen comes round the corner, Suddenly Ponsonby et al round to see her with Lady Churchill, Miss Phipps et al.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam not a fool. I know there is some skulduggery afoot. Something is going on here and I am not going to stand for it. Ponsonby et al. look terrified.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Dr Reid, I asked you to get to the bottom of Mrs Karim’s fertility issues and it seems nothing has been done.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Well, actually, Your Majesty, it was impossible to make a conclusive judgement for religious reasons.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well, did you examine the Munshi?

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: No, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well, examine the Munshi. The Queen heads off. Lady Churchill and Bertie hold back. 76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie. Bertie sheepishly follows. Dr Reid turns to Ponsonby.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: I did not do seven years at Edinburgh University to look at Indian dicks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Dr Reid stomps, unhappily, carrying his doctor’s bag towa house. INT. ABDUL’S COTTAGE. DAY Dr Reid with his stethoscope, as before. Abdul standing.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Trousers.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Dr Reid running at full pelt in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTYARD. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY
dialogues.text: Dr Reid running across the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr Reid running. He skids round a corner. INT. PONSONBY’S OFFICE. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY Reid bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Eureka! Ponsonby looks up. He’s riddled with the clap! 77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ponsonby and Reid knock on a bedroom door. A voice from i

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: of) Go away!

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Your Royal Highness. We come with important news about the Munshi! INT. BERTIE’S BEDROOM. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY Bertie is now in bed with a post-coital cigar. Lady Churc the bed. Ponsonby and Dr Reid have just explained the new

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The clap!

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: But we can’t possibly tell her. It would kill her stone d

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s not such a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: There’s more. It appears the father, far from being an Indian Eminent, is in fact a prison apothecary.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I received a telegram only this afternoon from Agra. My son visited the gaol himself. They are absolute nobodies. Bertie takes a puff while he thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Well, it sounds pretty conclusive to me. INT. QUEEN’S STUDY. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY Bertie knocks on the door and goes in. 78

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother, we have to see you... The Queen is sitting behind a small desk, Abdul intimatel side. Ponsonby and Dr Reid stand nervously before her.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (looking at Abdul) Alone.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Iam in the middle of my Urdu lesson.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mother, we come with very important news of a highly personal matter.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: I have nothing to hide from Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Iam afraid, Your Majesty, We have news concerning the Munshi. Proof, beyond any doubt, that Abdul Karim is a low-born imposter, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: But the Munshi is from a noble family and a long line of teachers.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: The Munshi was a mere clerk in a common gaol. She is silent. My own son has sent word from India and has actually spoken to the man in question.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: His family are completely uneducated. His father is a low apothecary.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: The Munshi didn’t even go to school, Mother. The man’s a complete fraud. There he is, overseeing the boxes. I’m ne in line and I can’t get anywhere near them. 79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is true, Your Majesty. You have been hideously duped a ignominously misused, Your Majesty. The Munshi is a blackguard and an arch deceiver. I am afraid Abdul and hi father are completely common. The Queen looks horrified at the proceedings. We have prepared a dossier. Ponsonby flourishes the dossier and slams it on the Queen seems flabbergasted. She looks at the dossier. The case s They stare at her with bated breath.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You despicable toads. Racialists! Spying?! Dossiers?! Picking on a poor defenceless Indian. Of course they don’ have qualifications. It’s completely different out there.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: But don’t you see, Mother, he’s using his position for hi own gain.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: And how does that make him any different to any one of you? How dare you look down on Abdul. How dare you defame his poor father. Bertie, I am ashamed that you are part of this. Abdul is a loyal, wise, sympathetic human being who has risen on his own merits. Not by endless backstabbing or family connections. I will not have this. Now. Repeat after me. I will be courteous to the Munshi. She stares at Ponsonby. He looks at Abdul, then reluctant

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I will be courteous to the Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: I will be courteous to the Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Bertie. All of you. ‘I will be courteous to the Munshi.’ 80

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will be courteous to the Munshi.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: It has become apparent that to get any respect in the Household one needs to be formally recognised. In which case, Abdul, I intend to give you a knighthood in the nex honours list. Ponsonby almost collapses.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Enough! This is absurd. We can’t protect you from this an further. The Queen stares in astonishment. The man is riddled with gonorrhoea. Stunned silence.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Gonorrhoea!?

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: Yes, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: Well, you’re a doctor. Why don’t you treat him?! Now get out of my sight. All of you. INT. OUTSIDE THE QUEEN’S STUDY. OSBORNE HOUSE. DAY Abdul, Bertie, Ponsonby and Reid come out of the room. Su Dr Reid loses it and pins Abdul up against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: REID
dialogues.text: You’re killing her, you pox-ridden Indian shit. Reid is strangling Abdul.

dialogues.speaker: ABDUL
dialogues.text: Doctor R— Abdul turns puce as Reid throttles him. Ponsonby tries to from Dr Reid’s clutches. 81

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr Reid! Be courteous! Reid comes to his senses and lets go. Abdul is shaken. INT. PONSONBY’S OFFICE. OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT The council is completely full with scores of staff and m Royal Household.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Knighted?!

dialogues.speaker: BIGGE
dialogues.text: Surely there is some law against it?

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: The man’s a common Indian, for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: MISS PHIPPS
dialogues.text: And a Muslim.

dialogues.speaker: ALICK YORKE
dialogues.text: She can’t just do what she likes.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: That’s right. We are the ones who make this palace work and we are being ignored and exploited. We have to stand up to this wanton bullying.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGE
dialogues.text: Exactly. This is a usurpation of the basic tenets of leadership.

dialogues.speaker: ALICK YORKE
dialogues.text: There are moral standards at stake. What is this? The Yea of the Munshi? They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: I propose we should rise up as a household and demand that she retracts. 82

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she’s the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: She is our sovereign. Her position is entirely based on t implicit contract she makes with us. Who manages the estates? Who is up at the crack of dawn preparing her breakfast? Toadying to foreign diplomats? Eating those interminable meals? Listening to the infernal drivel? Lor and Ladies, the time has come to say no. We must stand together and show her who really runs this ship.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: But this is a palace coup.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: It is an assertion of our inalienable rights as the arist of this country. The monarchy is not there by divine righ

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I think it is, actually.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Oh shut up.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGE
dialogues.text: I agree. We must resist these foreign intruders, for the of England, the Empire and St George.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: I say: either she drops this preposterous insult or we wi all leave.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ASSENT
dialogues.text: Hear, hear!

dialogues.speaker: MISS PHIPPS
dialogues.text: But isn’t this treason?

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: This is politics. The bloody unions do it. I don’t see wh shouldn’t have a go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooray!

dialogues.speaker: ALICK YORKE
dialogues.text: The Nabob has met his match. Yes! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: BIGGE
dialogues.text: Let’s show them what we are made of. More approval! That we are prepared to stand up to tyranny: for justice, right and for England! Huge cheers.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Are you with me? Unanimous assent. Are you with me? Unanimous assent and self-congratulation apart from:

dialogues.speaker: ALICK YORKE
dialogues.text: So what should we do? Nobody is sure.

dialogues.speaker: DR REID
dialogues.text: Somebody has to tell her. They all suddenly look nervous.

dialogues.speaker: BIGGE
dialogues.text: We should make a deputation.

dialogues.speaker: ALICK YORKE
dialogues.text: Won’t that look like a cabal?

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: I think you should go. You are the head of Household.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY
dialogues.text: I couldn’t possibly go, it would bring the position into disrepute. 84

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know her quite well, Mrs Tuck.

dialogues.speaker: MRS TUCK
dialogues.text: I’m just a dresser. What about Miss Phipps? Everyone’s attention is drawn to the skinny, mild-mannere Lady in Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: LADY CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Brilliant. You’re the maid of honour. Exactly the person break the news. Miss Phipps looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: INT. COUNCIL CORRIDOR. OSBORNE HOUSE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mrs Tuck fusses over Miss Phipps, making her look just so Dr Reid and Lady Churchill are there.

dialogues.speaker: PONSONBY

dialogues.text: Iam eighty-one years of age. I have had nine children, forty-two grandchildren, and almost a billion citizens. I am cantankerous, boring, greedy, ill-tempered, at times self and myopic, metaphorically and literally. I am, perhaps, disagreeably attached to power and should not have smashed the Emperor of Russia’s egg. But I am anything but insane.
